item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Mopman:

I’m not telling you to change it, just curious - why does CustomerPipe exist? Will there ever be another type of Pipe?

What do you mean? DefaultPipe is another type of pipe which has different attributes to CustomerPipe. They both have the superclass Pipe which contains all the attributes that they share.

item.title: Comparing two objects
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

[quote=“Aftermath, post:30, topic:422328”]How I would have written the equivalent of what you just pasted:

[code]
public void addOrderLine(CustomerPipe pipe1, int quantity, double cost) {
for(OrderLine o : orderLines) {
if(o.equals(pipe1)) {
o.incQuantity(quantity);
o.incPrice(cost);
return;
}
}

orderLines.add(new OrderLine(pipe1, quantity, cost);
System.out.println("Added pipe to order.");

}[/code]

Warning: You meant to include a .getPipe() after orderLines.get(i) when comparing to the pipe. I didn’t fix that in the modified code. As it stands, you’re comparing an OrderLine object with a pipe.[/quote]
Using foreach I suppose is a better way of doing it however after that statement the next part isn’t meant to be done unless it’s found nothing in the foreach e.g. this:
orderLines.add(new OrderLine(pipe1, quantity, cost);
System.out.println(“Added pipe to order.”);
is not meant to be done unless the foreach has found nothing.

item.title: Comparing two objects
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

[quote=“Brolapse, post:29, topic:422328”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=524998.msg3827270#msg3827270 date=1322279452]
You don’t use the boolean, is what he was saying.

Oh wait, it’s used in the initialization of OrderLine objects.
[/quote]
wait, WHAT?

For some reason the code sppt posted seems different to what I posted above him? Wtf happened I’m too drunk. It should look like this:

[code]
public void addOrderLine(CustomerPipe pipe1, int quantity, double cost) {
boolean alreadyThere = false;

            for (int i = 0; i < orderLines.size() && !alreadyThere; i++) {
                    if(orderLines.get(i).equals(pipe1)) {
                            orderLines.get(i).incQuantity(quantity);
                            orderLines.get(i).incPrice(cost);
                            alreadyThere = true;
                    }
            }
            if (!alreadyThere) {
                    orderLines.add(new OrderLine(pipe1, quantity, cost, orderLines
                                    .size())); // nb might need to incremnet this
                    System.out.println("Added pipe to order");
            }

    }[/code]

?? I thought he was referring to me using the boolean in a stupid way

WHAT[/quote]

How I would have written the equivalent of what you just pasted:

[code]
public void addOrderLine(CustomerPipe pipe1, int quantity, double cost) {
for(OrderLine o : orderLines) {
if(o.equals(pipe1)) {
o.incQuantity(quantity);
o.incPrice(cost);
return;
}
}

orderLines.add(new OrderLine(pipe1, quantity, cost);
System.out.println("Added pipe to order.");

}[/code]

Warning: You meant to include a .getPipe() after orderLines.get(i) when comparing to the pipe. I didn’t fix that in the modified code. As it stands, you’re comparing an OrderLine object with a pipe.

item.title: Comparing two objects
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

POJO!! lol. Right just rewrote the addOrderLine method so it uses the overriden .equals method

from:

[code]public void addOrderLine(CustomerPipe pipe1, int quantity, double cost) {
boolean alreadyThere = false;

	// search through orderline to see if we already have that in the list
	if (orderLines.size() > 0) {
		for (int i = 0; i < orderLines.size(); i++) {
			if (pipe1.getGrade() == orderLines.get(i).getPipe().getGrade()) {
				if (pipe1.getColours() == orderLines.get(i).getPipe()
						.getColours()) {
					if (pipe1.getInsulation() == orderLines.get(i)
							.getPipe().getInsulation()) {
						if (pipe1.getReinforce() == orderLines.get(i)
								.getPipe().getReinforce()) {
							if (pipe1.getChemRes() == orderLines.get(i)
									.getPipe().getChemRes()) {
								if (pipe1.getLength() == orderLines.get(i)
										.getPipe().getLength()) {
									if (pipe1.getDiam() == orderLines
											.get(i).getPipe().getDiam()) {
										orderLines.get(i).incQuantity(
												quantity);
										orderLines.get(i).incPrice(cost);
										alreadyThere = true;
										break;
									}
								}

							}
						}
					}
				}
			}
		}
	}
	if (!alreadyThere) {
		orderLines.add(new OrderLine(pipe1, quantity, cost, orderLines
				.size())); // nb might need to incremnet this
		System.out.println("Added pipe to order");
	}

}[/code]

to:

[code] public void addOrderLine(CustomerPipe pipe1, int quantity, double cost) {
boolean alreadyThere = false;

	for (int i = 0; i < orderLines.size() && !alreadyThere; i++) {
		if(orderLines.get(i).equals(pipe1)) {
			orderLines.get(i).incQuantity(quantity);
			orderLines.get(i).incPrice(cost);
			alreadyThere = true;
		}
	}
	if (!alreadyThere) {
		orderLines.add(new OrderLine(pipe1, quantity, cost, orderLines
				.size())); // nb might need to incremnet this
		System.out.println("Added pipe to order");
	}

}[/code]

with this added to OrderLine.java:

[code]
public boolean equals(Object o) {
if (o == null) {
return false;
}

	if (o == this) {
		return true;
	}

	if (!(o instanceof CustomerPipe)) {
		return false;
	}

	CustomerPipe p = (CustomerPipe) o;
	return pipe.getGrade() == p.getGrade()
			&& pipe.getColours() == p.getColours()
			&& pipe.getInsulation() == p.getInsulation()
			&& pipe.getReinforce() == p.getReinforce()
			&& pipe.getChemRes() == p.getChemRes()
			&& pipe.getLength() == p.getLength()
			&& pipe.getDiam() == p.getDiam();
}[/code]

Haven’t tested it properly yet as it still wont compile due to the retarded problem I said about above. I have the time to completely rewrite it(to solve the problem) but when I think about it it’s always going to come back to the problem that every method is going to want to be static so if I do rewrite it has anyone got any tips on a better class structure? Should I just throw all my methods into the gui class?

Thanks for all the help so far

edit:- also yo123 no point posting a stack trace it’s just the methods that can’t access Main.java from MainFrame.java(the gui class) that are throwing null pointers

item.title: Comparing two objects
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Thanks Lothy, got that problem all sorted. Now for a new one:

I have 2 classes, one to handle all the gui stuff and one to handle all the main stuff. These two classes need to be able to communicate. Right now the main creates an instance of the gui (e.g. MainFrame myFrame = new MainFrame()). I can then access all the methods of mainframe by using the instance e.g. myFrame.getFoo();

My problem is that inside my GUI class (MainFrame) I cannot access the methods from the main class from whence it was initialised. I know you can make the methods you need static however if I do that I end up having to make everything static because “Method cannot be referenced in a non static way” or whatever.

So apart from staticing everything up what do I do?

Read full topic

item.title: Comparing two objects
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

You’re wrong too, veer. You haven’t overridden equals in that example; you’ve overloaded it.

Proper solution:

public boolean equals(Object o) {
    if (o == null) return false;

    if (o == this) return true;

    if ( !(o instanceof Pipe) ) return false;

    Pipe p = (Pipe) o;
    return this.length == p.length && this.diam == p.diam && 
            this.color.equals(p.color);
}

Read full topic

item.title: Comparing two objects
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

So… much… bad.

  1. That’s not how you use a Comparator Ollie…
    http://download.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Comparator.html#compare(T, T)
Compares its two arguments for order. Returns a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as the first argument is less than, equal to, or greater than the second. In the foregoing description, the notation sgn(expression) designates the mathematical signum function, which is defined to return one of -1, 0, or 1 according to whether the value of expression is negative, zero or positive.

The implementor must ensure that sgn(compare(x, y)) == -sgn(compare(y, x)) for all x and y. (This implies that compare(x, y) must throw an exception if and only if compare(y, x) throws an exception.)

The implementor must also ensure that the relation is transitive: ((compare(x, y)>0) && (compare(y, z)>0)) implies compare(x, z)>0.

Finally, the implementor must ensure that compare(x, y)==0 implies that sgn(compare(x, z))==sgn(compare(y, z)) for all z.

It is generally the case, but not strictly required that (compare(x, y)==0) == (x.equals(y)). Generally speaking, any comparator that violates this condition should clearly indicate this fact. The recommended language is “Note: this comparator imposes orderings that are inconsistent with equals.”

  1. stork there is absolutely no reason I can think of to, assuming they are accessor methods, be using these accessor methods from where you are privileged enough to access fields directly…

  2. The hash-code implementation you derived, Brolapse, is inherently a naive one and will have many conflicts, making it unfit to estimate equality of pipes as Taharok has shown. Really, you shouldn’t ever only implement hash-code…

[b]The Gemini Twins: equals and hashCode[/b]

Equal hashCodes in general are not sufficient to ensure Object equality. However, if the hashCodes are not equal, you know the Objects can’t possibly be equal. Consider how many 50-character Strings there are (65535^50) and how many possible hashCodes there are (2^32). It should be obvious there are way more Strings than hashCodes. So the same hashCode has to be reused over and over for different Strings.
The default hashCode just uses the address of the Object and the default equals method just compares addresses. If you override one of these two methods, you must override the other to match. The rules are:

[ul][li]It is ok, unavoidable, but not desirable, if two Objects that do not compare equal have the same hashCode.[/li]
[li]Two Objects that compare equal must have the same hashCode.[/li][/ul]

  1. Just override equals… it’s exactly what is needed here, a way to check for semantic (vs identity) equality.

public class Pipe { ... /* semantic equality */ public boolean equals(Object other) { if (other != null && other instanceof Pipe) { Pipe _other = (Pipe) other; return _other == this || _other.length == this.length && _other.diam == this.diam && _other.colour == this.colour; } else { return false; } } }

Edit: As Lothy pointed out, I accidentally overloaded the method; I unintentionally had the parameter of type Pipe when I meant Object, as can be seen from the fact I still did an instanceof and kept a casted instance… oops.
Edit 2: What is the type of colour, anyways? It’s rather ambiguous here.

Read full topic

item.title: Comparing two objects
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

@Everybody who responded: What’s wrong with you guys?

Firstly, Ollie has completely broken the general contract of compare.
Secondly, a.hashCode() == b.hashCode() never guarantees equality. Especially when your hash function is only using addition to generate the hash.
As an example, consider a pipe with length = 20, diameter = 20 and the colour black. Now consider one with length = 19, diameter = 21 and the colour black. In this case, their hashCode() functions return the same value.

If a.hashCode() == b.hashCode() then a.equals(b) MIGHT return true.
It’s also worth noting that if a.equals(b) returns true then, in keeping with the general contract of equals and hashCode, a.hashCode() == b.hashCode() must also return true.

The main use of hashCode is by the collections API. Specifically, to speed things up, they check for hashcode equality and, if two hashcodes are equal, they then perform a call to equals.
The benefit here is obvious when you realise that String, among other classes, only calculates its hash value on the first call to hashCode – on consecutive calls, accessing the hashcode of a String is a constant time operation. Compare this to equals, which would be linear time.

Read full topic
